subject: Re: generate Suites for existing TestCases
msgSnippet: ... you ... collect a ... filename ... start ... Hello, my first idea was to find a tool generating a TestSuite as java-code from the java-sources and writing
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> When you say "write suites", what do you mean? What specifically do
you
> expect such a tool to do? It sounds like you want something to
collect a
> number of test case classes together to execute as a single suite.
>
> Ant (http://ant.apache.org) already helps collect all the TestCase
> classes from a certain part of the file system (matching by
filename
> patterns) and execute them as a large test suite. Look at its
> <batchtest> task.
>
> Also, look at JUnit-addons' DirectorySuiteBuilder, which you can
start
> using more quickly than Ant, but which /only/ does what the Ant
> <batchtest> task does.
> --

Hello,
my first idea was to find a tool generating a TestSuite as java-code
from the java-sources and writing the suite source-file to the
filesystem. One file/class for each package containing all TestCases
of the package and all TestSuites of direct subpackages.
E.g. code like this:
package mainpackage;

import mainpackage.subpackage.Subpackage_Suite;
import junit.framework.*;

public class Mainpackage_Suite
{
static public Test suite() {
TestSuite aSuite = new TestSuite();

aSuite.addTestSuite(MyTestCase.class);
aSuite.addTestSuite(My2ndTestCase.class);

aSuite.addTest(Subpackage_Suite.suite());

return aSuite;
}
}

JUnitDoclet does something equal, but it also generates
TestCase-skeletons i donÂ´t want to be created.

The ant-task and the DirectorySuiteBuilder collect all tests and
execute them, but do not generate java-code. May be this is sufficient
for my purpose. I will check it out. Anyway thanks for your hints.

Helge
